text: Rodger M. Koefod KIA 50 years ago, April 27th. 1969-Bihn-Dihn Province, Vietnam Nam. He and 55,000 others not to be forgotten.

What a cool thing to do for those who can't make the trip. You can't help to be moved whenever you see all the names on that wall. My dad never got to see it, but  I have. My mom says he was never the same after coming home. I never really knew what happened until after he died at 49. I was 21. One of his Army friends told me how a group of his buddies were killed by a bomb that a kid they had met & took care of, set off one day. My dad had gone to take a leak, that's the only reason he survived. We knew to never ask or talk about it. We couldn't slam doors bc it made him jump out of his skin & my mom would spank us & send us to our room. He was an alcoholic but not a mean one. He never slept either. People don't understand how much damage war does not only physically but mentally. All this immigrant racism shit pisses me off too, bc my dad & his buddies were all hispanic, & volunteered to go, even though they had little children at home. I was born in '66. He came home when I was like 5. I remember being afraid of him bc I didn't know him. Thank you for what you are doing. ✊🇺🇸When you thank a veteran, do it for me, too.

answers.text: @north_side_chick I feel you...truly... I know what's it's all about... My Dad was the Illinois Rep. for Vietnam Veterans of America throughout my childhood and I couldn't be prouder... I'm so fortunate to have been able to see what it took to actually help Veterans and to be a part of it... Lot of early mornings and late nights, and every one of them worth it...

text: Thank you for offering to do this, that's amazing ❤️ my dad was in Korea in the Vietnam era... My uncle volunteered for a second tour so he wouldn't have to go to Vietnam. Some amazingly brave people were there, that's for sure
